{{enzyme
| Name = Acetaldehyde dehydrogenase (acetylating) EC_number = 1.2.1.10
| CAS_number = 9028-91-5 IUBMB_EC_number = 1/2/1/10 GO_code = 0008774 image =
| AcetaldehydeDehydrogenase-1NVM.png width = caption = Crystallographic
| structure of the acetaldehyde dehydrogenase from [[Pseudomonas|Pseudomonas
| sp]]. ; 
}} 'Acetaldehyde dehydrogenases' () are dehydrogenase enzymes which catalyze the
conversion of acetaldehyde into acetic acid. The oxidation of acetaldehyde to
acetate can be summarized as follows:

:CH 3CHO + NAD + + CoA â acetyl-CoA + NADH + H +

In humans, there are three known genes which encode this enzymatic activity,
ALDH1A1, ALDH2, and the more recently discovered ALDH1B1 (also known as ALDH5).
These enzymes are members of the larger class of aldehyde dehydrogenases.

The CAS number for this type of the enzyme is [9028-91-5].
